</core_stats_on_map> </continent_stats_map> <featurettes> <item> <featurette_id>na_featurette_wildfires</featurette_id> <title>Fighting the Flames - Wildfires in North America</title> <position_slot>featurette_left_top</position_slot> <body_text>Wildfires are powerful, fast-spreading fires that burn through forests and grasslands. They happen often in places like California or western Canada, where hot, dry weather turns trees and plants into easy fuel. As Earth’s climate warms, droughts become more common, making it easier for sparks—from lightning or a campfire left unattended—to grow into a raging blaze.
When wildfires strike, they can destroy homes, harm wildlife, and fill the air with thick smoke. Firefighters use helicopters, planes, and special tools to contain the flames. Communities plan ahead with fire safety rules, and everyone can help by following local guidelines and using fire responsibly. Together, we can protect people, animals, and our forests from going up in smoke.</body_text> <assets> <item> <asset_id>na_ft1_photo_firefighters</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>Featurette <featurette_id>na_featurette_suburban_life</featurette_id> <title>Suburban Life – America’s Unique Neighborhoods</title> <position_slot>featurette_left_bottom</position_slot> <body_text>In the United States, many families choose to live in suburbs—neighborhoods filled with single-family homes, green lawns, and quiet streets just outside big cities. After World War II, more people bought cars and wanted more space. Suburbs grew quickly, and soon millions of Americans were commuting to work from their cozy houses.
In other countries, more people stay close to downtown, often using trains or buses to get around. In American suburbs, most people rely on cars to reach stores, schools, and offices. While suburbs offer peace and privacy, they can lead to more traffic, more gasoline use, and more pollution. Still, suburbs remain a big part of how many Americans live and shape their everyday lives.</body_text> <assets> <item> <asset_id>na_ft2_photo_suburban_street</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <featurette_id>na_featurette_natural_wealth</featurette_id> <title>America’s Natural Wealth—Resources and Industry</title> <position_slot>featurette_right_top</position_slot> <body_text>From fertile farmland to underground minerals, the United States holds a treasure chest of natural resources. Rich soils grow abundant crops like wheat and corn. Deep below the surface, oil, gas, and minerals power factories and fuel cars. Skilled workers turn these raw materials into everything from smartphones to skyscrapers.
Over time, these resources helped the U.S. grow into a strong economy, creating jobs and building cities. Farmers feed the nation and the world, miners provide metals for tools and machines, and engineers guide energy from deep underground to light up our homes. By understanding and protecting these resources, people can keep the country thriving for generations.</body_text> <assets> <item> <asset_id>na_ft3_photo_grain_field</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <featurette_id>na_featurette_transportation_networks</featurette_id> <title>Roads, Rails, and Rivers – Connecting America</title> <position_slot>featurette_right_bottom</position_slot> <body_text>Look at a map of North America and you’ll see a web of highways, train tracks, and rivers tying distant places together. The Interstate Highway System lets you drive across the country, while railroads carry heavy loads like coal and grain. Rivers and canals allow ships to move goods cheaply and efficiently, and airplanes link people to far-off cities in just a few hours.
These transportation networks bring fresh produce to your grocery store, deliver packages to your doorstep, and connect friends and families. Without them, the economy would slow down, and everyday life would be harder. Whether by road, rail, water, or air, these routes keep America’s heart beating and its people moving forward.</body_text> <assets> <item> <asset_id>na_ft4_photo_trucking</asset_id> <type>photo</type>
